|DorlandsSuf = }} Anatomically, a 'nose' is a protuberance in vertebrates that
houses the nostrils, or nares, which admit and expel air for respiration in
conjunction with the mouth. Behind the nose are the olfactory mucosa and the
sinuses. Behind the nasal cavity, air next passes through the pharynx, shared
with the digestive system, and then into the rest of the respiratory system. In
humans, the nose is located centrally on the face; on most other mammals, it is
on the upper tip of the snout.
